title: Network Topology
content: A Network Topology is the arrangement with which computer systems or network devices are connected to each other. Let's explore some common topologies you'll encounter.

title: Star Topology
content: In a star topology, devices connect directly to a central hub. It's easy to set up and troubleshoot. If the hub fails, the network does too.

title: Bus Topology
content: A bus topology is like a straight highway with stops along the way. All devices connect to a single central cable. Data travels along the cable, and each device decides whether to receive it or not.

title: Ring Topology
content: Picture a circular chain, like a relay race. In a ring topology, each device connects to exactly two others, forming a loop. Data moves in one direction. If a device fails, it can disrupt the entire ring.

title: Mesh Topology
content: Visualize a web where everything is interconnected. In a mesh topology, every device connects to every other device. It's robust and can withstand device or cable failures without affecting the network.

title: Hybrid Topology
content: Consider a mix of the above. Hybrid topologies combine different types to meet specific needs. You can have star-connected hubs within a larger mesh, for example.
